Name: Why Does E=mc2? (And Why Should We Care?)

ReviewList.Text: It's a great feeling to come back tired from work and pick up such a book. After all, like most people I rarely have time to ponder seriously about the universe and the meaning of time and space.I am a high school French teacher so my training in science is rather limited. But after a few hours spent thinking about time,space, distance, energy and matter with Cox and Forshaw,I felt enlightened and rejuvenated! It really read like a thriller, whenever I put the book down I could not stop thinking about it and at dinner I could not shut up about it. The more my friends asked me questions about what I read the more I felt like going back and re-reading until I could explain it in my own words. Now that I am done with it, it's haunting me, driving home or playing with my cat; it keeps me thinking...

For someone who never found the light clocks and shrinking meter sticks of the standard attempts to explain relativity without math very comprehensible, this book does a better job of presenting more intuitive models for nonintuitive concepts.  You have to accept that Einstein's theories, which flow naturally out of the existence of a universal speed limit, have been experimentally validated:  the muon that should decay in 2.2 milliseconds actually does take 29 times more seconds to "die" when it is accelerated to almost the universal speed limit.  In other words, from the standpoint of an observer at rest with respect to the muon, the muon lives longer as it gets closer to the speed limit.  The authors tell you to imagine a spacetime world where speed and time, added together, are conserved.  So as you use up more of your velocity vector, you use up less time, so your time slows down from the standpoint of an observer.  A photon, which is going at the universal speed limit, apparently does not age.  While the layperson can "get" this concept, since it is not that dissimilar to Newtonian concepts, when you sit back and think about it, it unfortunately still makes no sense, and your rational brain keeps saying, "there must be some other explanation for this." The authors say that from the standpoint of the muon, which still thinks it is living 2.2 milliseconds, the space that it's traversing must shrink.  At other points they tell us the muon itself is shrinking at high speeds.  Are both of these true? Is the natural consequence of this that all photons are everywhere at once -- is all of space just a point to a photon?  If photons have no mass then why do massive objects, like black holes, have an effect on them?  The authors wait until the last few pages to disclose that the standard model, which the book is based on, only works as is in a world where nothing has mass, and that to connect the model to the real world, scientists must find a Higgs boson particle that mediates the relationship between the field that supposedly exists all around us and everything that is in it.  Without that field and the Higgs boson, there is no explanation within the current model for mass.  In other words, our entire understanding of the world of quantum mechanics and relativity may soon turn out to be based on mistaken assumptions.  The definitive book for the layperson on this subject has yet to be written, but in the meantime, this is a good place to start.

Every few years I read a book on physics written for the lay person.  Most of them are pretty good, but make the mistake of covering too much ground i.e. relativity, quantum mechanics and string theory.  This book focuses on relativity and the most famous equation in scientific history E = mc2.  As the title suggests, the book does an admirable job in making the theory accessible and also delivers on the promise of explaining why we should care.  It is the only book of its type to take the mystery out of why the speed of light should be related to energy or mass.  I am not giving much away by revealing that the speed of light is somewhat of a red herring.  "C", it is explained, is the cosmic speed limit.  It also happens to be the speed of light because it can be derived that it is the speed of a massless particle.  The writing is witty and engaging.  The small amount of math presented does not go beyond basic high school trigonometry.

Throughout the book the author apologizes lengthily for boring the reader who is skilled at math, AND to the reader who is not skilled. Appropriate, since on one page of the book you can find the explanation that "2 squared = 4, 10 squared = 100...", while on another page you can find the equation for the Standard Model! I enjoy physics books for the non-scientist (such as by Brian Greene, Michio Kaku) even though they were often over my head, but this book is half under and half over, making it of less value.

I feel this book has given me the best understanding of Einstein's theory I have managed to assimilate to date.  This is a difficult topic but the book does reveal that at least some of it is no different than understanding the ratios in everyday math associations.  The genius of the equation is that Einstein found ratios in elements of the universe that, until he came up with the equation, no one else had considered to be related.  But, since time, mass and energy do appear to be connected by an ever mounting body of experimental evidence that supports the equation, it also means that the ratios captured in the equation indicate how the amounts of the constituents of the equation flow into balance as the different elements change in relationship to each other.  The book still remains top heavy on the math part for me but it did give me enough clarity to be able to get it into a prose format for myself that did seriously improve my sense of understanding of this amazing formula.

The first 2/3 of the book present an excellent nicely paced progression on concepts and history leading to a practical understanding of Relativity.  However, it jumps the track right at the punchline.  I have a Physics degree, so I knew where this book was trying to go.  However, I found myself rereading the last chapters trying to appreciate how they were getting to E=MC2.  Not what you want from a layman Physics book!  However, overall it is a commendable book and worth a read.

I am halfway through the book. So far it is very entertaining and easy to read. Actually, perhaps it is too easy to read. It seems like the authors wanted to target people with no background whatsoever in math or science, so the authors sometimes spend more time than expected explaining why v=x/t implies t=x/v and other simple things of that sort. Certainly you can skip those parts though.

WHY DOES E=MC2 AND WHY SHOULD WE CARE comes from two physicists who offer basic ideas on relativity and its applicability to everyday life. Their survey of both the theory and its wider-ranging applications connects relativity to life in terms any lay reader can understand, from considering ideas of mass, energy and light to everyday examples illustrating theories. Any general lending library will find this a key acquisition.

This is a marvelous book, which provides an amazingly straightforward insight in the geometry of the space time continuum and explains why the speed of light is the most important physical constant which keeps our universe together. Furthermore, it is intriguing that in Minkowski 's mathematical framework for general relativity, the famous Pythagorean Theorem, which defines distance in Euclidean Geometry, just changes its sign to describe distance in the curved Riemann geometry for space time. Just changing the sign gives irrefutable proof that the speed of light cannot be exceeded. It should be observed that the speed of light is basically the speed of particles without mass (like photons). And here the magic realtionship between the speed of "light" and the still not very well understood concept of mass is established (we first need to find the Higgs particle). This further reveals in a very simple and straightforward manner Einstein's Special and General Relativity and demonstrates that e=mc2. I never expected modern physics to be this easy. It now becomes simple to live in 4 dimensions

I admire this book enormously. It's the very best of it's kind. Jeff Forshaw is an impressive thinker in the field, particularly well-regarded for his work on the phenomenology of elemental particle physics at the University of Manchester, and his work at the LHC. Brian Cox, of course, is a good-looking star in the UK, with a cute accent. But it's the intelligence and grace behind the vision here, the generosity of the clear and compelling prose. I've heard Jeff Forshaw speak, and I'm in no doubt that he's the brain behind the method and attack of this impressive work on a subject that's notoriously difficult to explain to non-scientists. I knew a fair amount before I began the book, but I know much more now, and have new ways to make sense of the field to my friends. What a clever book, what a remarkable team. I can't wait for the next book and to see Jeff and Brian do a TV science- show for children, using puppets and fuzzy toys to explain this usually impenetrable science. I'd love to be on such a team. What a piece of work this book is. More hat's off!

I have read a few books on this topic written for mortals like me & this has been by far the best book that explained the topic to most part. The idea behind the book is that this very complex and intriguing topic would be explained in simple terms with the reader being asked to understand Pythagoras theorem only. The idea of clocks moving slowly is explained really well with this approach but the best explanation in my view is the concept of absolute space, while I did not feel the same about space-time, even though the author had made immense effort to do so. While I understand the topic is too complex without fundamental understanding basic algebra the premise of knowing only Pythagoras theorem is very short lived in the book, also I would have liked to more about Newton’s view of space and time than what is made available in the book, still I commend the author for writing such a great book and recommend this book as best starter on this topic.

I have a degree in physics and I enjoyed this book (which I read mainly because the authors are from my university), it's entertaining and informative, mostly clear and easy to comprehend. There's good coverage of relativity (special and general), plus some coverage of particle physics (standard model), and just a dash of quantum mechanics. My only problem is that while the authors address how length and time change as velocities approach the speed of light, I did not find any direct mention of how mass appears to change (rest mass versus relativistic mass). Therefore the book may sometimes be confusing to anyone unfamiliar with modern physics (which is the target audience) ... for example, the book describes how photons have energy, but also have zero mass, yet the entire book is obviously about E = mc^2, an equation which apparently does not make any sense (non-zero = zero?) given the incomplete (or at least implicit) presentation provided by the book. For some readers, this may be a confusing presentation flaw, and probably should have been more explicitly addressed.

The authors do an excellent job of explaining and clarifying concepts that are really difficult to grasp.  They do this in a very understandable and interesting way.  They cover the relativity of time, the constant velocity of light, and many other related concepts from a very basic view all the way down to the underlying equations.  Perhaps the most important concept covered is 'spacetime' as an invariant.  Their entertaining and illuminating prose is illustrated by their discription of this idea:  "...everything hurtles through spacetime at the same speed,.... Light just happens to use up all of its spacetime speed quota on motion through space, and in so doing travels at the cosmic speed limit." This book is an intellectual treat that, for most, will require several visits -- a welcome prospect.

Great introductory science. Using only minimal math, this book gives us a very clear explanation of what Einstein's wonderful equation actually means and explains very lucidly how this leads to an understanding of space and time that is radically different from Newton. We are introduced to spacetime, a notoriously mind-bending concept, with expert guidance. Without glossing over the difficulties in abandoning our intuitive concepts of absolute space and time, we are lead down the same paths that the science of modern physics has traversed in its journey from Aristotle's earth centered universe to Einstein's spacetime, and we are left with a real understanding. And as a bonus we are also treated to a brief introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics and its so-called master equation.

I've read two biographies of Einstein (Clark's and Isaacson's), Bodanis' "biography" of E=MC2, and a smattering of Richard Feynman's writings for those not schooled in physics but I learned the most about special relativity from this book. It is great. I wish that I was young enough to begin really learning about physics. I understand that Professors Cox and Forshaw are writing a similar type of book about quantum mechanics. I'll bet it will more accessible to me than Gribbin's, In Search of Schrodinger's Cat; but maybe I should reread Gribbin.

This book is for the layperson such as myself. Whereas I would love to have an in-depth understanding of the concept of energy and how it applies to space-time, it can't be done without years of dedicated school work. With that said,  I think this book itches just the right the spot in every wannabe physicist. Brian Cox and Jeff Forshaw make you work just hard enough with simple math concepts. I found myself re-reading the equations 3-4 times and understanding them without reaching for a pen and paper. If you have graduated Highschool your experience should be like mine. "Why Does E=mC^2" explained things as far as far as it possibly could without the reader being a physicist and without making too many logical leaps.

I find the subject matter of this book fascinating and I have enjoyed others touching on the same basic subject. However, although the preface promises to illuminate the subject with mathematics no more difficult than the Pythagorean theorem, I found that this was a bit misleading... There are lots of formulas embedded within the text and, with my very basic mathematical education, I found the going very tough. Ulitimately, I abandoned the book somewhere around three-quarters of the way through. I am not qualified to comment on the accuracy of much these authors have to say but I would counsel those without a lot of experience working with mathematics and physics problems to be cautious in spending money on this book.

If only my brain could keep up with the authors of this little book.  E=mc2 is not the simplest concept in the world, and trying to understand spacetime and similar concepts puts a strain on the old gray matter.  Although I do not thoroughly understand all of this,I know more than I did before.  This is definitely a book I will read again.

This book brings more interesting details regarding the formula E=mc2  especially for a non-physicist such as myself.  Unfortunately my math is weak so I probably missed some of the finer points.  It is a wonderful addition to string theory, quantum physics, and Higgs books.

Very clearly written. I could follow the reasoning quite easily. Indeed the whole deduction of Einsten's equation is a masterpiece of simplicity. I enjoyed the book very much and strongly reccommend it to all non-phisicists who wish to know a little bit more on the subject.

A very entertaining and engaging explanation of the most amazing insights into space, mass, energy and time.  The majority of it is written at a very understandable level. It is the best book of this type I have read so far.

I have been an amateur follower of physics, astronomy and quantum physics for many years now and have read many books on these subjects. Without doubt, "Why Does E = mc2" is among the best two, if not the best.  I finally feel I have a basic understanding of why "C" (the universal constant - miscalled the speed of light) applies in our Einstein macro world and the fundamentals that underpin it - such as causality and "universality" and why we can theoretically go forward, but not backwards in time. Same for Space / Time.  Obviously the authors skipped over some of the deeper stuff (such as why other different formulae - other than a variation of Pythagorus - were not investigated in establishing the space - time graph). But I appreciated this simplification process, which helped me better concentrate on the key points. I have never before seen such a good explanation of the Standard Model formula (in fact I have never before seen this amazing formula) and the naming of 12 key components of the Standard Model formula  (which I now keep in my notes file in my phone for easy reference).  Thank you Brian Cox and Jeff Foreshaw for helping me better understand the world we live in.  I very much enjoyed your "tweedy" delivery which made me feel I was your guest in your personal library.
A intriguing look at the history and reasoning that went into development of the theory. Before reading this I had no idea what it meant.
The latter third of the book falls down in trying to explain admittedly complex concepts in an "understandable" way. Disappointing

Finally I get relativity! I've found Brian Cox to be an excellent practical demonstrator in his TV shows and those skills transfer well to this book. This is very much a layman's guide to some of the most fundamental facts about our universe, and there are some pretty astounding revelations in it. I only have a couple of gripes firstly there are some important points that they identify as being important so reiterating them a couple of times is fine, but to "labour the point" on some things would be an gross understatement as some things are repeated 4 or 5 times in 3 or 4 pages and it just get's ridiculous (we get it!!) and then they'll casually slide in some random "important" piece of the puzzle in a paragraph and just assume that you know what they're talking about. In addition to this some of their statement are ambiguous and I found myself puzzling over whether the a statement means something is or isn't true.
This is a great book. Brian Cox is one of the best teachers alive today. I finaly understand the math behind relativity.
An excellent analysis of Physics most revered equation, not too dumbed down, but not too Ph.D. level either.

Excellent focus on explaining the concepts clearly  - I learnt a lot that I had never been able to grasp before. It claims to use nothing more complicated that Pythagoras, but be prepared for a bit more than that, and a retreat into equations later in the book that to me obscured the concepts more than I was prepared for. Some of the powerful insights of the discoverers were put forward rather too suddenly and I couldn't always grasp how they were arrived at. I would have preferred more measured steps in these places. In summary I value what I have learnt from this book, and imagine that if I need to, I can re-read and work though those parts that I didn't get the first time.

The book itself does a good job of covering a complex subject. Unfortunately the formulas in the Kindle version are unreadable. For instance, "c^2 - v^2" in the original is formatted as "c^2 u v^2" in the Kindle version. The symbols v and u are used interchangeably in formulas involving velocity. The print version doesn't suffer from these problems. If you are inclined at all to try to understand the formulas in this book do yourself a favor and skip the Kindle version and find a print copy of the book.
Wonderful!  Entertaining and informative.  This one stays on my shelf.

This book was just what I needed. The detail is perfect, and I'm finally understanding spacetime and how math reveals the theories. While others have criticized this book for too much or too little math, I find it just right. Brian's earthly examples about spacetime, which he then expands into space itself, helped me finally get what has been confusing me for awhile. I can't wait to read his next book, and am truly grateful for this one! I recommend this book to any and all who are interested in relativity.

I have purchased 3 or 4 books over the years to help me understand Einstein's Relatively.  This book, which has a goal to explain E=MC2 to us physics idiots has the side benefits of explaining a LOT of related physics with little or no math.  I will need to read it twice or even three times to fully understand up to my own capabilities but the reading is enjoyable and informative in all chapters.  My goal is to understand this stuff well enough to try and teach a little in High School.  We will see.

While no science book is ever one-size-fits-all, this book is excellent.  If some part of the book is confusing, find another book about that topic, read it, and return to this book.  You will be rewarded for your effort!  These general science books are a journey, not a destination.  I loved this book and I have a pretty solid math and physics background.  That said, I learned a whole new way of viewing our world.  I'm on to the authors next book "The Quantum Universe."

For a clear description of spacetime just go to Wikipedia. It does in a few paragraphs what this book attempts to do, and doesn't, in chapters. Wikipedia uses about the same amount of mathematics and doesn't spend pages apologizing. In addition if there's a term you don't understand, just click on it and Wikipedia will take you there. I am going to put this book into recycling  and not even give it away because it is muddle.

You ever have a lazy day, where you go to watch tv and you can't find your remote but your too lazy to be bothered to change the channel. Well that happened to me awhile ago back in HS and it was stuck on the science channel, and a marathon of Brian Cox shows came on and sense then i have always enjoyed this mans books, and his tv appearances. He is one of the people who made me want to go into science, and so far this book has been a fun read.

This book is a good exposition of special relativity, special relativistic effects, and the underlying reasons why those effects are what they are.  Very interesting from a philosophical point of view, because as the theory of relativity has been tested and refined since Einstein's work, we understand much more about the effects than when they were first proposed.  Fairly mathematically-intensive, this book won't cater to those who don't like math or geometry.

Not a patch on the original e=MC2 by Michael Bodanis (I think; it's been a while); This one's too earnest, too folksy. too patronising and neither fish nor fowl with one eye on serious science devotees and the other on tyros.  Perhaps it improved a bit towards the end but I bailed about halfway thru which is almost unheard of.  Sorry guys

This book begins with statements directed towards a general audience, but includes information valuable to those with a mathematics or conceptual background. If you want to take your knowledge of Relativity to a greater depth, this is the book for you. (My other favorite is still "Einstein's Universe", by Nigel Calder.)

This book is a detailed exploration of the wonderful ideas of Albert Einstein. The authors went to great lengths simplifying and explaining some of the math behind the greatest formula of the past century (perhaps of all time). A joy to read, this book will change the way you see your space and time on this planet.

This interesting  book provides a clear understanding of the Einstein' famous theories using an approach that is straightforward and compelling. The authors succeeded in avoiding  the complexities of the math  but failed regarding the physics. Notwithstanding, the science adepts will appreciate reading the book.

Brilliant book. I am breathless with anticipation for Cox's next literary adventure. Its that good. I am trained in physics and engineering and I enjoyed every page. It is succinct and the analogies used to explain very difficult concepts are well though and functional. I would recommend this book to anyone.

Brian Cox does an excellent job in explaining space-time, and the implications of E=mc 2. This should be included in every physics class as supplemental reading because simply saying light speed is constant is one thing but actually taking the time to consider the consequences is another.

As a non qualified scientist, but a very interested novice into how and what we are, I found the book well crafted. A challenge in places but that is the books fascination. I not only understood it - well at least from a laymans point of view, but I learned so much. Great read.

The book is in excellent condition. The price was very good too. It was an international shipment so the shipping fee was kind of expensive and it took the book like a month to get to my address. But I definitively recommend the book. The language is clear and concise.

Brian Cox did a great job explaining the importance of physics and why it matters in our everyday life. We encounter physics everyday and we take it for granted. The more we understand the easier it is to comprehend why life is so complex and beautiful.

When I did physics at uni I never understood the physics as well as this book explains. It is a little light on the maths to comunicate a real picture of the complexity of the field, but no amount of maths gave me as clear an insight as this book.

To make a great book small; It does the explaining in an easy and well-written way, but some part are a bit hard to follow, and they could have done it without the math. But if you are interested: Buy it and read it, you will not be disappointed.

While the book meandered in a couple of places, the overall aim of showing how much of standard physics is dependant or can be derived from Einstein's equations was explained in a progressive and logical fashion. A very accessible book for all.

The authors enjoy sharing their perspective and passion for physics with everyone not just the initiated few. This is an important and often fogotten step in the advancement of science.  It ... is .... a wonderful book and inspires the mind.

I really enjoyed this book and I would recommend it to everyone from the novice all the way up to physics students. I would only say that you must really read this book with full focus to understand the theories which make E=mc^2 wonderful.

This is an informative and well written book. It is an easy read even for those not familiar to the concepts presented. The examples are helpful for clarification and there are a few diagrams throughout to aid with representation.

Brian Cox is a fantastic author and scientist. He makes learning about complex topics interesting and fun. I definitely learned a lot after reading this book. If you are interested in physics then I highly recommend this book.

Just take your time, read for enjoyment, and understanding coupled with wonder will follow. Great book! Try the simple maths, but don't worry if you don't get an "ah-ha!", the text will carry you nicely. Read it.

Easy and entertaining as a novel, deep and clear as a text book. It is fascinating to discover the meaning of Einstein's and hundred of scientists' contribution to decipher the cosmos. Physics that borders philosophy

Brian Cox has an uncanny ability to bring physics down to a level which can be readily understood and appreciated by the common people.  His explanation of Einstein's equation was simple and straight forward.

As a guy with a physics degree, I'm often asked this question. This book has given me a few ideas for giving better answers, but it's pathologically math averse and that often gets in the way of clarity.

I got this book (on my Kndle) because I was interested in learning about this famous equation. The book taught me that and much more, especially about the speed of light and it did so in laymans terms.

Pauvres terriens habitués à se déplacer à quelques centaines de km à l'heure au maximum. Grâce à Brian Cox, ce que l'étude de la relativité nous décrit devient descriptible dans un diagramme classique.
I believe Cox does an excellent job at explaining several physics concepts to both the beginner and intermediate physics enthusiast. I appreciated the book immensely and would highly recommend it.
Very well written, the descriptions and explanations of Einsteins achievements are presented in a way that can be appreciated by someone like me who has not much previous exposure to physics.
I found this book quite difficult for my 50 year old Physics major background.  Great to get in touch with the detail of Einstein's reasoning and to remain in some awe at his genius
I like the science and have seen Brian Cox on television but this book wasn't super.  I didn't love it or hate it.  It didn't engage me even though I have an interest in science.
Written in a very readable linguistic style but not at the compromise of technical accuracy. Understandable physics in the Feynman /Sagan style. Congratulations .... Vince
Try to derive the equation valid in  hiperbolic space from the Pythagoras` theorem leads to some darkness in  readers` mind.However the outcome is very well explained.
Extraordinarily accessible; this book gives the reader a way to understand the truly mind blowing state of physics today. You will walk away truly humbled by this
As always, Brian Cox makes the most undecipherable concepts easy to understand for lay people. I really enjoyed it, even if I skipped the math a couple of times.
I bought this book to help myself to better understand Einstein's theory. Not being a physicist, I'm still confused but its well written and a good reader.
This is a great read for understanding Einsteins simple, but provocative equation. The authors presume nothing but common sense and some simple Maths.
Clear ( mostly ) some things I would have preferred explained again - but that may be a reflection of me rather than Brian's writing.
Interesting, Very good explanation of the Einstein theory, it uses math in a way you will understand.... Approved and understood :-)
Some of the attempts to reduce obtuse cosmology into lay language require re-reading, but the end result is worth the extra effort.
This is the first book from which I could (almost) really understand Einsten's special and general theory of relativity. Very fine.
Too complicated for the laymen, despite what the Preface says. You will need a very good grounding in more then just basic Physics.
Great simple explanations of what is clearly a tough subject.  Does inevitably get more complicated as the book progresses though
This book is very clearly written and presents the nuances of relativity theory and makes for an interesting read for anyone.
The wit and charm of Cox is endemic through this very well thought out and explained trip through some fundamental physics.
Love the subject. It is very complex and you may need to read some pages and chapters 1-5 times!! Still love the book
Excellent account of the origin and contents of the theory of relativity. I'd say its physics for the rest of us.
Fascinating insights given in this well written book. Anyone interested in science generally should read it.
the math is a bit difficult for a medical person.  it is an improvement over most similar books.
One of the most thorough reviews and explanations of special relativity I have ever read.
Not much different or easier to understand than Einstein's own book on the subject.
Phenomenal explanation of some complicated concepts, excellent read!
Interesting understandable to me a mathematically challenged person.
So far even I can follow the logic. Very clear explanations.
Excellent en language narrative. Well worth the cost.

This book is a real challenge.  The authors try to present difficult concepts (for me) in ways that we mortals can understand.  Most of the time they succeed.  I haven't finished the book yet, so I still don't know why I should care.
Great material but very boring explanations.

Great read. Hopefully you guys do another one about the larger standard model equation toward the end of the book. Maybe after they fire off the LHC into Brian's large toy Atlas if they ever turn that bad boy on.
Excellent! Everything I hoped for..

This book is neither an academic text nor suitable for the lay reader. It purports to explain Einstein's famous equation in terms that even non-physicists can understand, and in this it fails miserably. It makes leaps and assumptions of knowledge that are only suitable for those steeped in Physics, and its math is difficult to understand. For those capable of understanding what the authors are saying, this book will be boring. For those with only a basic understanding of relativity who are seeking to gain a deeper insight, only disappointment and frustration await them.
interesting powerful
ok brian cox
Good book

The book is a good explanation of the Physics contained therein.  I have an M. S. In Physics from the early '70s, so some of it is new to me.  HOWEVER, the editing is so poor that the explanations often suffer--sometimes a lot.

This book is very inspiring and interesting. If you want to know the true meaning of Einstein's field spacetime eqation and the solution of dark matter and dark energy, please also go to read the book "Theories of Everything by Logic". You will find out the answers!
This is an easy reading that takes you from simple geometry to the advance general relativity.  I does not requiere prior knowledge in higher mathematincs. High school level is sufficient.
This Is A Great Book IMHO, I've Watched Wonders Of The Universe(All Episodes) & Brian Cox Really Makes Everything Easy To Understand.
Easy reading, very interesting.
Very enjoyable read.
great

I am not sure what has happened, but I had hoped to give this as a gift to my son on his graduation in Law. It is a topic of special interest as we both say Einstein's letter with the formula in it.
